Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Administered By Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description: The BC Employment and Assistance Program for Persons with Disabilities provides disability assistance and supplements to provide greater independence for people with disabilities, including security of income, enhanced well-being, and participation in the community
Eligbility: Persons with disabilities and Low Income
Expenditures (2018/19):
Total: $2,417M. Breakdown:
  • $1,416M in Entitlements
  • $1,001M to CommunityLiving
  • Admin. and appeal are under IA

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Administered By Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description: The BC Employment and Assistance (BCEA) program is an income and asset tested program that provides monthly income assistance and employment supports to people in need who have no other resources. The program is intended to help move people from income assistance to sustainable employment and to provide income assistance to those who are unable to fully participate in the workforce.
Eligbility: Low Income, low assets
ChildPrograms:
Other Eligibility Requirements by Program:
  1. Expected-to-Work: 3 week work search
  2. Not Expected to Work: single parent with child under 3 or child with medical condition, or persons fleeing abuse, or cannot legally work in Canada, or persons facing a direct and life-threatening health need or in a continuing care facility;
  3. Persons with Persistent and Multiple Barriers to Work: health condition that impedes employment (including an addiction) + an additional barrier to employment such as homelessness, fleeing abuse, former child in care, or criminal record ;
  4. Medical Condition: short-term medical condition
Expenditures (2018/19):
Total: $551.5M
Breakdown:
  • $391M in Entitlements
  • $146M for Management
  • $1.8M to Appeal Tribunal
  • $12.7M for Executive Services
Budget (2019/20): $425M in Entitlements + $156M in Management + $1.8M to Appeal Tribunal + $12.9M for Executive Services

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Administered By Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description: Hardship assistance is intended to meet the essential needs of persons or families who are not eligible for Income Assistance or Disability Assistance for a number of reasons specified by regulation. Hardship assistance is not an entitlement, but may be provided at the discretion of the Minister according to legislative and regulatory criteria.  It is provided on a temporary basis for only one month at a time.  Eligibility for hardship assistance must be re-established each month.
Eligbility: low-income, immediate need, and not eligibile for IA or DA because: waiting for EI or other income, assets or income in excess, identity not established, SIN required, or strike/lockout.

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description: CLBC is the provincial crown corporation that funds supports and services to adults with developmental disabilities, as well as individuals who have a diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) or Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder and who also have significant difficulty doing things on their own. CLBC provides community support, employment support, inclusion support, residential support, behavioral support, and respite for families.
Eligbility: Adults with developmental disabilities, autism, or FASD who require support with daily tasks.

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description: The Senior's Supplement is a provincial top-up to federal OAS/GIS. The Senior's Supplement ensures a conditionally guaranteed minimum income level for residents of BC and is paid to low-income residents of BC who are 65 years of age and older and who are receiving OAS/GIS or the federal Allowance.
Eligbility: Low-income seniors 65 years+ receiving OAS/GIS or the Allowance

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Administered By Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description: Includes 22 different programs available through the BC Employment and Assistance program (BCEA) to assist with specified needs and circumstances. Eligibility for supplements is generally determined through consultation with Ministry staff (See Supplement chart for more details).
Eligbility: Recipients of IA, DA, and/or HA + must meet specific supplement eligibility criteria
ChildPrograms:
General Supplements:
  1. Automatic Child Benefit Top-up
  2. Community Volunteer (only if grandfathered)
  3. Camp Fees
  4. Christmas Supp.
  5. Clothing Supp.
  6. Co-op Share Purchase Supp.
  7. Confirmed Job Supp.
  8. Crisis Supp.
  9. Family Maintenance Supp.
  10. Funeral Costs
  11. Guide/Service Dog Supp.
  12. ID Supp.
  13. Moving, Transport, & Living Costs
  14. Natal Supp.
  15. Pre-Natal Shelter Supp.
  16. School Start-Up Supp.
  17. Security Deposit
  18. Temporary Child Benefit Top-up
  19. Transport Supp. (Only DA)
  20. Transport to Alcohol & Drug Facilities
  21. Travel Supp.
  22. Utility Security Deposit
Expenditures (2018/19): $365M for General + Health Supplements provided through SDPR (and not through BC Health or PBC)
Budget (2019/20): $380M for General + Health Supplements provided through SDPR (and not through BC Health or PBC)

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Administered By Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description: Includes 18 programs available through the BC Employment and Assistance program to assist with specific health needs and circumstances.
Eligbility: Recipients of IA, DA, and/or HA, OR persons eligible for Healthy Kids, Medical Services Only, Life Threatening Health Need, or Transitional Health Services.
ChildPrograms:
Health Supplements:
  1. Supp. for Alcohol & Drug Treatment
  2. Alterantive Hearing Supp.
  3. Basic Dental
  4. Dental: Crown & Bridge
  5. Dental: Orthodontic
  6. Emergency Dental
  7. Diet Supp.
  8. Extended Medical
  9. Infant Formula Supp.
  10. Med. Equipment: Hearing
  11. Med. Equipment: Orthoses
  12. Med. Equipment & Devices (i.e. wheelchairs)
  13. Med. Supplied
  14. Med. Transport
  15. Nutrition Supp.
  16. Optical
  17. Short-term Nutrition Supp.
  18. Tube Feed Supp.
Expenditures (2018/19): $365M for General + Health Supplements provided through SDPR (and not through BC Health or PBC)
Budget (2019/20): $380M for General + Health Supplements provided through SDPR (and not through BC Health or PBC)

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Administered By Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description:
Provides continued access to specific health supplements to certain categories of former recipients of DA.
One of the major goals of MSO is to assist persons with the Persons with Disabilities designation to obtain and maintain employment by allowing them to retain their premium-assisted Medical Services Plan coverage as well as other health supplements as they move from disability assistance into financial independence.
Eligbility: Former recipients of DA, or former recipients of IA with a PPMB designation, who either have employment income that disqualifies them from DA/IA or federal transfers (OAS/GIS, CPP) that disqualifies them from DA/IA

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Administered By Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description: Access to medical equipment, medical supplies, or medical transportation to persons who are not otherwise eligible but who face a direct and imminent life-threatening health need and have no other resources to meet that need.
Eligbility: B.C. residents not eligible for IA, DA, or HA, but is eligible for MSP Premium Assistance, and has a direct and imminent life-threatening health need and no other resources to meet that need.

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Administered By Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description: Provides continued access to certain health supplements for up to one year to families with children who leave IA for employment. The intent of THS is to assist families with children to obtain and maintain employment by allowing them to retain their premium-assisted MSP coverage as well as other health supplements while they move from income assistance into financial independence.
Eligbility: A member of a family unit that ceased to be eligible for IA as a result of employment income, and has a dependent child.

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description: Provides support for those on Employment Insurance (EI) with skills training and employment assistance.
Eligbility: Current and former EI claimants,or persons who have made EI contributions in last 5 of 10 years, or unemployed persons
ChildPrograms:
Programs under LMDA:
  1. Single Parent Employment Initiative
  2. Employment Assistance Services
  3. Apprentice Services
  4. Assistive Technology Services
  5. Community and Employer Partnerships (CEP)
Number of Recipients (2018/19): 89,035 Work BC clients and 219 CEP inclusion groups in 24 projects

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Social Development and Poverty Reduction
Description: The Healthy Kids Program provides coverage for basic dental treatment, optical care and hearing assistance to children in low-income families, who are not in receipt of income assistance, disability assistance or hardship assistance.
Eligbility: Low income, not a recipient of IA, DA, or HA

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Description: This program provides services to help immigrants find skilled employment in BC using the education and experience they bring to Canada.  Services are customized to the participant's needs including support specific to in-demand occupations
Eligbility: A immigrant or Refugee or New to Canada who is unemployed or underemployed

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Administered By Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Description: Through the Aboriginal Community-Based Training Partnerships (ACBTP) program, the Ministry funds partnerships between public Post-Secondary institutions (PSIs) and Indigenous communities to deliver education and training programs within communities
Eligbility: First nations or Aboriginal or Inuit

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Description: Emergency financial assistance is provided by public post-secondary institutions to assist students who have urgent unforeseen financial needs that may prevent them from finishing their studies; students to contact the Aboriginal Student Services at their institution. Subject to available funding.
Eligbility: First nations or Aboriginal or Inuit experiencing a short-term, unforeseen financial crisis

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Description: The Community Adult Literacy Program (CALP) is a community-based literacy initiative to promote and deliver adult literacy programs and services across the province; the goal of CALP is to increase the literacy and numeracy levels of adults 19 years and older through one on one or small group learning environments
Recipients (2016/17): 4,151 (unclear if this is programs funded or persons served)

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Full Program Name: BC access grant for students with permanent disabilities
Description: This program helps full-time students with a permanent disability with the cost of education by replacing approximately $1,000 in B.C. student loan funding
Eligbility: Person with disabilities

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Description: This program waives tuition fees for B.C. students who are former youth in care between 19 and up to their 27th birthday who are attending a B.C. public post-secondary institution.
Eligbility: Former youth in care between 19-26 years old

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Description: StudentAid BC helps eligible students with the cost of their post-secondary education through loans, grants, scholarships, and other programs

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Full Program Name: Youth Educational Assistance Fund for Former Youth in Care
Description: This program provides grants of up to $5,500 per program year to former BC youth in care students between 19 and 24 years of age. Students may receive a maximum of four grants
Eligbility: Former youth in care who are 19-24 years old
Conditions: Attending post-secondary or other employment training

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Description: The ISTDF supports Indigenous community members (on and off reserve) in British Columbia's North and Lower Mainland to acquire the skills needed to respond to emerging resource-based opportunities
Eligbility: First nations or Aboriginal or Inuit

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Description: Assists industry and employers understand and respond to changing labour market demands. The Program provides funding for partnership-led projects that address broader sector and regional labour market issues within B.C.'s diverse economy; five types of projects funded - engagement and planning, research, strategy development, strategy implementation, and evaluation

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Advanced Education, Skills & Training
Description: Labour market programming
ChildPrograms:
WDA Programs:
  1. BC Employer Training Grant
  2. Community Workforce Response Grant
  3. Skills Training for Employment

Description: Affordable rental housing is for people who have a low to moderate incomes but may not be eligible for subsidized housing. Affordable rental housing is housing with rents equal to, or lower than, average rates in the private-market
Budget (2019/20): $126M Operating Grants + $305M Project Grants to provide 42,190 units

Description: The Home Adaptations for Independence (HAFI) program provides financial assistance for home modifications for eligible low-income individuals with mobility or health issues. Subject to available funding.
Eligbility: Person with disabilities and low income

Description: An initiative aimed at providing individuals in identified at-risk groups facing homelessness with portable rent supplements and support services to help them access rental housing in the private (non-subsidized) housing market. Includes: homeless outreach program, homeless prevention program, and BCH health services
Eligbility: Homeless

Description: A range of programs and services available in BC to assist people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness
Eligbility: Homeless

Description: Independent Living BC (ILBC) is a subsidized, assisted-living program that provides housing with support services to seniors and people with disabilities. Persons who qualify live in theirr own unit in an assisted living residence.
Eligbility: Person with disability or seniors

Description: The Rental Assistance Program provides eligible low-income working families with cash assistance to help with their monthly rent payments.
Eligbility: Households who are employed and low-income with dependent child(ren), paying more than 30% of gross monthly income to rent

Description: The Seniors' Supportive Housing Program provides housing and support services to low income British Columbians who are 55 years of age or older, and people of any age who have a disability or diminished ability. The numbers here exclude the number for Independent Living BC.
Eligbility: Low income person who is either a person with diminished ability or disability, or a senior 55 years +

Description: The Shelter Aid for Elderly Renters (SAFER) program helps make rents affordable for BC seniors with low to moderate incomes. SAFER provides monthly cash payments to subsidize rents for eligible BC residents who are age 60 or over and who pay rent for their homes
Eligbility: Senior 60+ years, low income, and paying more than 30% of gross monthly income to rent

Description: Subsidized housing is long-term housing for low income people who permanently reside in British Columbia. Rental fees are calculated on a rent geared to income basis (30% of household total gross income, subject to minimum rent based on # of people). The numbers here are for non-RAP, non-SAFER subsidized housing.
Eligbility: Low Income

Description: Supportive housing is subsidized housing with a range of on-site, non-clinical supports, such as life-skills training, and connections to primary health care, mental health or substance use services.
Eligbility: Low income persons with mental health or substance abuse issues

Description: Provides housing services and supports for women and children who have experienced violence or are at risk of experiencing violence. Includes: transition houses, safe homes, and second-stage housing.
Eligbility: Women ages 19+ with or without dependent child(ren)
Budget (2019/20): $33.8M to support 864 units + $46.3M in project grants

Description: The basic personal tax credit is a non-refundable tax credit every BC resident is entitled to claim on his or her income tax return. It is the amount of income that can be earned before paying any provincial income tax multiplied by the tax rate for the lowest tax bracket. This amount changes year to year in order to keep up with inflation. In 2019, the base amount is $10,682.
The B.C. Child Opportunity Benefit provides a tax-free monthly payment to families with children under the age of 18. It will be implmented in October 2020.
Eligbility: Dependent child(ren)

Description: The BC climate action tax credit helps offset the impact of the carbon taxes paid by individuals or families. The amount of the credit depends upon the family size and adjusted family net income.The credit is combined with the federal goods and services tax/ harmonized sales tax (GST/HST) credit into one quarterly payment
Eligbility: Low Income

Description: The Home Renovation Tax Credit for Seniors and Persons with Disabilities assists eligible individuals 65 and over and persons with disabilities with the cost of certain permanent home renovations to improve accessibility or be more functional or mobile at home
Eligbility: Person with disabilities eligible for the Disability Tax Credit or seniors

Description: The Sales Tax Credit is a program designed to offset the cost of sales tax for low-income taxpayers and their families residing in BC as of December 31st of the tax year
Eligbility: Low Income
Conditions: Income-tested, must file taxes plus the additional form

Description: The B.C. tax reduction credit is a non-refundable tax credit for individuals who have a net income below a certain amount. The credit is reduced by a percentage of an individual's net income over the threshold amount. For the 2018 tax year, the net income threshold is $20,144 and the reduction factor is 3.56%.
Eligbility: Low Income

Full Program Name: Fuel Tax Refund for Persons with Disabilities
Description: The fuel tax refund program allows people with a qualifying disability to request a refund of the provincial motor fuel tax paid in B.C. on fuel used in an owned or leased vehicle.
Eligbility: Person with disabilities

Description: Tax deferment is a low interest loan program that helps qualified B.C. homeowners pay their annual property taxes on their principal residence.
Eligbility: Person with disability or senior or a surviving spouse of any age with minimum 25% equity in home. A homeowner may qualify for the Families with Children program if they are a parent, step-parent, or are financially supporting a child.
Budget (2019/20): $240M (amount deferred) for estimated 52,000 renewals + 13,000 new applicants

Description: The home owner grant reduces the amount of property tax you pay for your principal residence. Supplemental grants are available for sub-populations: seniors, veterans, and people with disabilities
Expenditures (2019 YTD):
Expenditures (2019)
  1. General: $437M
  2. Persons with disabilities: $6.3M
  3. Senior: $373M
  4. Veteran: $21,000
  5. Low Income Grant Supplement for People with Disabilities or Seniors: $379,000
  6. Low Income Grant Supplement for Veterans: $2,700
Recipient (2019 YTD):
Recipients (2019 YTD)
  1. General: 896,000
  2. Persons with disabilities: 8,500
  3. Senior: 414,000
  4. Veteran: 30
  5. Low Income Grant Supplement for People with Disabilities or Seniors: 600
  6. Low Income Grant Supplement for Veterans: 10

Description: The Legal Services Society offers a range of free legal services to all British Columbians, with priority given to people with low incomes. Services include legal information, advice, and representation

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Children and Family Development
Administered By Full: Ministry of Children and Family Development
Description: The ACCB helps families with the cost of child care, depending on factors like family size, type of care and household income. In most cases, the child's caregivers pay the reduced child care fee, and the child care provider receives the payment.
Eligbility: Dependent child requiring childcare because recipient is: searching for work, attending school, is employed, or has a medical condition that interferes with their ability to care for their child.

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Children and Family Development
Administered By Full: Ministry of Children and Family Development
Description: For persons who had been foster care or had a Youth Agreement, this program helps cover the cost of things like housing, child care, tuition and health care while they go back to school, or attend rehabilitation, vocational or approved life skills program
Eligbility: Formerly in foster care or under a Youth Agreement, and 19-26 years old.
Conditions: Attending post-secondary, rehabilitation program, vocational program, or approved life skills program.

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Children and Family Development
Administered By Full: Ministry of Children and Family Development
Description: Assists with the day-to-day costs of running a licensed child care facility. Applied for by the child care provider and paid directly to the child care provider.
Eligbility: Licensed child care facility.

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Children and Family Development
Administered By Full: Ministry of Children and Family Development
Description: The purpose of the CCFRI is to help enhance childcare affordability through parent fee reduction funding and stabilized childcare fees.  Parents do not need to apply for the fee reduction. Child care providers need to apply in order to receive funding. Participation in CCFRI is voluntary.
Eligbility: Licensed child care facility receiving CCOF.

Description: Provides health care coverage for workers injured at work. Once reports are received from an injured worker, their employer, and their health care provider(s), and the claim is accepted, health care benefits cover the cost of the health care services and supplies that are considered reasonably necessary to treat the injuries. This may include medical treatments, hospitalization, medical supplies, rehabilitation, and medications.
Eligbility: Injured at work.

Description: If an injury at work results in a disability, and that disability is likely to impair future earning capacity, the injured worker may be eligible for a permanent disability award. The amount of the award depends on the circumstances of the claim.
Eligbility: Injured at work resulting in a disability that impairs future earnings.

Description: Wage-loss benefits compensate workers who lose pay due to a work-related injury or illness. Benefits continue until the worker is able to participate in modified work or return to usual duties.
Eligbility: Injured at work.

Description: Fair PharmaCare helps B.C. families pay for eligible prescription drugs, dispensing fees and some medical.
ChildPrograms:
Pharmacare Programs:
  1. General Fair Pharmacare
  2. Residents of Residential Care Facilities (Plan B)
  3. Recipients of IA/DA/HA (Plac C)
  4. Cystic Fibrosis (Plan D)
  5. Children in the At-Home program (Plan F)
  6. Psychiatric Medication (Plan G)
  7. Pallitive Care (Plan P)
  8. First Nations (Plan W)

Description: The BC Farmer's Market Nutrition Program helps low-income individuals and seniors gain access to healthy, locally grown food through the provision of coupons. Each household is eligible to receive a minimum of $21/week in coupons which can be redeemed at participating farmers markets. The program runs throughout the summer months.
Eligbility: Low-income and pregnant or dependent children or senior

Full Program Name: BC Education and Training Savings Grant
Description: The BC Government will contribute $1,200 to eligible children (who are beneficiaries of an RESP) through the BC Training and Education Savings Grant (BCTESG). The BCTESG requires no matching or additional contributions
Eligbility: Child(ren)

Full Program Name: CommunityLink Funding and Vulnerable Student Supplement
Description: CommunityLINK (Learning Includes Nutrition and Knowledge) funding is designed to support the academic achievement and social functioning of vulnerable students. Programs and services can include breakfast, lunch and snack programs, academic supports, counseling, youth workers and after-school programs.
Number of Recipients (2018/19): 60 school districts, i.e. all school districts receive CommunityLink. 25 school districts receive VSS.

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Energy, Mines, and Petroleum Resources
Description: A grant payment to avoid disconnection of service may be available to residential customers who have fallen behind on their BC Hydro bill due to a temporary financial crisis, such as a loss of employment or income, unanticipated medical expenses, or a death in the family
Eligbility: Overdue payments to BC Hydro and unexpected financial crisis

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Energy, Mines, and Petroleum Resources
Description: The Energy Conservation Assistance Program (ECAP) provides income-qualified residential customers with a free home energy evaluation, energy-saving products and advice
Eligbility: Low Income

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Public Safety & Solicitor General
Description: The Crime Victim Assistance Program (CVAP) assists victims, immediate family members and some witnesses in coping with the effects of violent crime. It provides financial benefits to help offset financial losses and assist in recovery.
Eligbility: Victim of crime resulting in financial loss - replaces lost income

Responsible Ministry Full: Ministry of Public Safety & Solicitor General
Description: You may qualify for help to travel to interviews, hearings and other justice-related proceedings. The Victim Travel Fund provides funds up to $3,000.00 for a family or victim to attend justice-related proceedings in B.C. Eligible expenses may include meals, accommodation and the most cost effective form of travel
Eligbility: Victim of crime

Description: Rent Banks offers short term funding (loans) available to families and individuals that are at risk of eviction or essential utility disconnection due to a temporary shortage of funds. BC Budget 2019 has proposed $10M funding for a province-wide rent bank.
Eligbility: Low income persons who rent primary residence and are expereincing a temporary, unexpected crisis, and have proof they can repay the loan

Description: Low income seniors and other eligible recipients living in an area served by BC Transit or TransLink may receive a reduced-cost bus pass
Eligbility: Low-income senior receiving either the GIS, Allowance, IA, or DA

Description: A means-tested program to be administered by CMHC that helps first-time home buyers by advancing up to 10 percent of the home purchase price for CMHC-insured mortgages so they can take out a smaller mortgage and keep monthly payments lower.
Eligbility: First-time home buyer and income < $120,000

Full Program Name: Housing Internship for First Nation and Inuit Youth
Description: This program provides financial assistance to help First Nations and Inuit businesses and organizations create housing-related internships for youth. These internships can provide much-needed work experience and on-the-job training to youth.
Eligbility: First nations or Aboriginal or Inuit

Description: Program invites municipalities and other stakeholders to propose new ways to break down barriers in the creation of new housing.  Merit-based competition will fund winners $300 million in funding

The GST/HST new housing rebate allows an individual to recover some of the goods and services tax (GST) or the federal part of the harmonized sales tax (HST) paid for a new or substantially renovated house that is for use as the individual's, or their relation's, primary place of residence, when all of the other conditions are met.
Eligbility: House price < $450,000, and newly built or substantially renovated home

Description: The Home Buyers' Plan (HBP) is a program that allows individuals to withdraw up to $25,000 in a calendar year from their registered retirement savings plans (RRSPs) to buy or build a qualifying home for themself or for a related person with a disability
Eligbility: First time home buyer

Description: The Canada Education Savings Grant (CESG) is money that the Government adds to a Registered Education Savings Plan (RESP). An Additional amount of CESG is available to eligible children from middle- and low-income families. The Canada Learning Bond (CLB) is money that the Government adds to a Registered Education Savings Plan (RESP) for children from low-income families. This money helps to pay the costs of a child’s full- or part-time studies after high school .
Eligbility: Child(ren)
Conditions: Hold an RESP. For the Grant, must deposit money into the RESP.
ChildPrograms:
Programs:
  1. Canada Education Savings Grant
  2. Canada Education Savings Grant addition
  3. Canada Learning Bond

Description: Individuals with an RDSP can apply for a Canada Disability Savings Grant or Bond. The Canada Disability Savings Bond is a government contribution to the Registered Disability Savings Plans (RDSPs) of low and modest income Canadians.
Eligbility: Eligible for the Disability Tax Credit.

Description: The Skills Link program is a component of the Government of Canada's Youth Employment Strategy (YES). Through funding of organizations, the Skills Link program helps youth overcome barriers to employment, develop a broad range of skills and knowledge in order to participate in the current and future labour market and to promote education and skills as being key to labour market participation
Eligbility: Youth

Description: Through Employment and Social Development Canada, creation of 40,000 work-integrated learning opportunities/work placements: $631.2 million over 5 years for 20,000 new work placements per year plus $150 million over 4 years to ESDC create partnerships with business to create a further 20,000

The Allowance is a benefit available to people aged 60 to 64 who have a low income, who are living in Canada, and whose spouse or common-law partner has died or whose spouse or common-law is receiving the GIS.
Eligbility: Ages 60 - 64, married, common-law or widowed, low income
ChildPrograms:
Allowance Programs:
  1. Allowance for the Survivor
  2. Allowance for People Aged 60 to 64

Description: The Apprenticeship Incentive Grant (AIG) and the Apprenticeship Incentive Grant for Women (AIG-W) helps pay for expenses while training as an apprentice in a designated Red Seal trade. The Apprenticeship Completion Grant (ACG) is a taxable cash grant for registered apprentices who successfully complete their program.
Eligbility: Enrollment or completion of apprenticeship program
ChildPrograms:
Programs:
  1. Apprenticeship Completion Grant
  2. Apprenticeship Incentive Grant
  3. Apprenticeship Incentive Grant for Women

Description: The Canada Pension Plan (CPP) provides contributors and their families with partial replacement of earnings in the case of retirement, disability or death. Almost all individuals who work in Canada outside Quebec contribute to the CPP.
Eligbility: Varies
ChildPrograms:
Programs within CPP:
  1. CPP: Retirement Pension
  2. CPP: Disability Benefit
  3. CPP: Children's Benefits
  4. CPP: Death Benefit
  5. CPP: Survivor's Pension
Recipients (2018):
1. CPP: Retirement Pension:947,350
  2. CPP: Disability Benefit: 60,147
  3. CPP: Children's Benefits: 23,989
  4. CPP: Death Benefit:3,018
  5. CPP: Survivor's Pension:185,127
Expenditures (2018):
1. CPP: Retirement Pension:$6,437M
  2. CPP: Disability Benefit: $757M
  3. CPP: Children's Benefits: $83.5M
  4. CPP: Death Benefit:$64.3M
  5. CPP: Survivor's Pension:$740M

Full Program Name: Canadian Benefit for Parents of Young Victims of Crime
Description: Parents or legal guardians who have taken time away from work and suffered a loss of income to cope with the death or disappearance of their child or children may be eligible for federal income support of $4,50 per week.
Eligbility: Employed, and reduction in employment earnings, and child was a victim of a crime

Description: The Employment Insurance (EI) program provides temporary income support to unemployed workers while they look for employment or to upgrade their skills. The EI program also provides special benefits to workers who take time off work due to specific life events (illness; pregnancy; caring for a newborn or newly adopted child, a critically ill or injured person, or a family member who is seriously ill with a significant risk of death). Workers receive EI benefits only if they have paid premiums in the past year and meet qualifying and entitlement conditions.
Eligbility: Varies

Description: The Guaranteed Income Supplement (GIS) provides a monthly non-taxable benefit to Old Age Security (OAS) pension recipients who have a low income and are living in Canada
Eligbility: Low income senior

Description: The Old Age Security (OAS) pension is a monthly payment available to seniors aged 65 and older who meet the Canadian legal status and residence requirements
Eligbility: Senior

Description: The Government of Canada offers student grants and loans to full-time and part-time students. Grants and loans help students pay for their post-secondary education.
The Government of Canada offers student grants and loans to full-time and part-time students. Grants and loans help students pay for their post-secondary education.
Savings account for persons with a disability.
Eligbility: Must be eligible for the Disability Tax Credit.

Description: Savings account for education.
The Government Employees Compensation Act (GECA) provides compensation to federal government employees who are injured while on the job or become ill because of their work
Eligbility: Injured at work, and federal employee.

Full Program Name: War Veteran's Funeral and Burial Assistance
Description: Funeral and burial assistance is provided throughthe Last Post Fund, a non-profit organization, to help pay for funeral and burial services, including a military gravestone, for eligible Veterans.
Eligbility: No available money in estate

Description: A disability benefit is a tax-free, financial payment to support your well-being. The amount you receive depends on the degree to which your condition is related to your service (entitlement) and the severity of your condition, including its impact on your quality of life (assessment).
Eligbility: Veteran or Canadian Armed Forces

Description: The Income Replacement Benefit provides income assistance to maintain income while taking part in the VAC rehabilitation program.
Eligbility: Veteran or Canadian Armed Forces, and diminished or no earnings

Description: The Canadian Forces Income Support is a tax-free monthly benefit. It helps low-income CAF Veterans who no longer qualify for the Earnings Loss Benefit, after participating in the Rehabilitation program.
Eligbility: Veteran or Canadian Armed Forces, and Low Income

Description: Helps in financing veteran's education
Eligbility: Veteran or Canadian Armed Forces

Description: The Exceptional Incapacity Allowance is a tax-free monthly payment that recognizes that your serious illness or injury has a significant effect on your quality of life.
Eligbility: Veteran and is a person with a disability

Description: The attendance allowance helps to cover the cost of hiring a caregiver to assist you in your day-to-day life. The amount you can receive is based on the level of care you need, from occasional to full-time supervision and care.
Eligbility: Veteran and is a person with a disability who needs assistance with daily living activities

Description: The Detention Benefit is a tax-free lump-sum payment for Veterans or CAF members who were detained by an enemy, opposing force or terrorist group while serving in the Canadian Armed Forces.
Eligbility: Detained or evaded capture by an enemy, opposing force, or terroist group (after Apr. 2006)

Description: The Veterans Independence Program provides funding for services such as grounds maintenance, housekeeping, meal preparation, personal care, and professional health and support services.
Eligbility: Low-income veteran

Description: The Veterans Independence Program for survivors provides annual funding to help cover the cost for services such as grounds maintenance and housekeeping.
Eligbility: Low-income or person with a disability and a survivor of veteran

Description: If you buy special clothes to accommodate your disability you may qualify for this allowance. For example, you may wear a brace, splint, or prosthetic that requires specially-made clothes, or that causes extra wear and tear. You can also use the monthly allowance to pay for your damaged clothes to be mended.
Eligbility: Veteran with disability where disability affects clothing

Full Program Name: War Veteran's Prisoner of War Compensation
Description: Prisoner of War Compensation is a tax-free benefit for Veterans of the Second World War and the Korean War, who were detained or evaded capture for more than 30 days.
Eligbility: Detained/POW during WWII or Korean war

Description: The War Veterans Allowance (WVA) is a tax-free, monthly benefit to help low-income war Veterans and their dependents or their survivors.
Eligbility: Low-income veteran of WWII or Korean war

Description: The Death Benefit is paid to a spouse or common-law partner and the dependent children of a Canadian Armed Forces member who died as a result of a service-related injury or illness.
Eligbility: Survivor of veteran or WWII or Korean war

Description: The basic personal tax credit is a non-refundable tax credit every Canadian resident is entitled to claim on his or her income tax return. It is the amount of income that can be earned before paying any federal income tax multiplied by the tax rate for the lowest tax bracket. This amount changes year to year in order to keep up with inflation. In 2019, it is $12,069 x 15% = $1,810.
The Canada child benefit (CCB) is a tax free monthly payment made to eligible families to help them with the cost of raising children under 18 years of age.
Eligbility: Dependent child(ren)

Description: To help Canadians with the cost of training fees. Eligible workers between the ages of 25 and 64 accumulate a credit balance at a rate of $250 per year, up to a lifetime limit of $5,000. The credit can be used to refund up to half the costs of taking a course or enrolling in a training program.

The Canada Workers Benefit is a refundable tax credit that is intended to supplement the earnings of low income workers and improves work incentives for low-income Canadians. Replaces the WITB. Will be implmented in tax year 2019.
Eligbility: Low Income
ChildPrograms:
Programs within CWB:
  1. CWB: General
  2. CWD-Disability: top-up to CWB for persons with a disability.

Description: The child disability benefit is a tax-free monthly payment made to families who care for a child under age 18 with a severe and prolonged impairment in physical or mental functions.
Eligbility: Dependent child(ren) with a disability, and eligible for the Disability Tax Credit and the Canada Child Benefit

Description: The disability tax credit (DTC) is a non-refundable tax credit that helps persons with disabilities or their supporting persons reduce the amount of income tax they may have to pay.
Eligbility: Person with disabilities

Description: Individuals who have a permanent mobility impairment and cannot safely use public transportation, can request a refund of part of the federal excise tax on the gasoline you buy. A qualified medical practitioner must certify the impairment
Eligbility: Persons with a disability who cannot safely use public transit

Description: The GST/HST credit is a tax-free quarterly payment that helps individuals and families with low and modest incomes offset all or part of the GST or HST that they pay
Eligbility: Low Income

Description: The medical expense tax credit is a non-refundable tax credit for healthcare expenses paid.
Eligbility: Eligible medical expense

Description: Savings account for retirement.
Tax free savings account

Full Program Name: Indian Residential Schools Resolution Health Support Program
Description: The Indian Residential Schools Resolution Health Support Program (IRS RHSP) provides mental health, emotional and cultural support services to eligible former Indian Residential School students and their families throughout all phases of the Indian Residential School Settlement Agreement
Eligbility: First nations or Aboriginal or Inuit; and former Indian Residential School students and family members

Description: The Non-Insured Health Benefits Program provides eligible First Nations and Inuit with coverage for a specified range of medically necessary health-related goods and services when not covered through private insurance plans or provincial/territorial health and social programs.
Eligbility: First nations or Aboriginal or Inuit with no other health insurance

Description: The Federal Internship for Newcomers (FIN) Program offers eligible newcomers a chance to gain valuable temporary work experience and training opportunities with Canadian federal, provincial and municipal organizations.
Eligbility: Immigrant or Refugee or New to Canada

Description: The Immigration Loans Program provides financial help to refugees selected for resettlement.
Eligbility: Immigrant or Refugee or New to Canada
ChildPrograms:
Programs:
  1. Right of Permanent Residence Fee Loan
  2. Assistance Loans

Full Program Name: Language Instruction for Newcomers to Canada
Description: Permanent residents and protected persons can take language classes at no cost. They are funded by the government.
Eligbility: Immigrant or premanent resident

Description: The Government of Canada gives resettlement help to Convention Refugees Abroad. Immediate and essential services are delivered by Service Provider Organizations (SPOs), generally within the first 4-6 weeks of a newcomer’s arrival in Canada. Activities include the following: providing temporary accommodation, providing basic orientation to Canada, life skills training and financial orientation, assisting in finding permanent accommodation, and referring to other settlement programs.
Eligbility: Immigrant or Refugee or New to Canada

Full Program Name: First Nation & Inuit post-secondary student support program
Description: The program aims to improve the employability of First Nations and eligible Inuit students by providing them with funding to access education and skills development opportunities at the post-secondary level.
Eligbility: First nations or Aboriginal or Inuit

Description: The Western Canada Business Service Network (WCBSN) is a group of independent organizations that receive WD funds to help Western Canadians start, grow and expand their businesses.
One-year program at RMC designed to provide students of Indigenous heritage with individual, group, and cultural experiences that will help build leadership and life skills.
Eligbility: First nations/aboriginal/inuit

Description: Located in municipalities throughout BC, recreation financial assistance programs provide low income residents with access to basic recreation programs and services at a reduced cost.
